recipes.name: Butter Chicken
recipes.instructions:
1. Begin by gathering all ingredients required for preparing butter chicken, ensuring vegetables are washed, spices are measured, and proteins are cleaned.
2. Prepare 500g Chicken by chopping, marinating, soaking, or rinsing as traditionally required for the dish.
3. Heat oil, ghee, or butter in a kadhai or pot over medium flame until hot enough for sautéing.
4. Add aromatics such as onions, ginger, garlic, curry leaves, or whole spices and sauté until fragrant and lightly golden.
5. Add ground spices like turmeric, red chili, coriander, garam masala, or regional masalas and roast briefly to release their flavors.
6. Incorporate tomatoes, curd, coconut, tamarind, or other base ingredients depending on the dish and cook until the mixture thickens.
7. Add the prepared main ingredient along with any vegetables, dals, or meat pieces and mix thoroughly so they absorb the masala.
8. Pour in water, stock, or coconut milk (if applicable) and bring the mixture to a gentle boil.
9. Reduce heat to low and allow the dish to simmer until the main ingredient cooks fully and flavors deepen.
10. Taste and adjust seasoning, adding salt, spice, tanginess, or sweetness as needed.
11. Finish with garnishes such as coriander, ghee, cream, fried onions, or tempering (tadka) depending on regional preparation.
12. Serve hot with roti, naan, rice, dosa, or the traditional pairing for the dish.

1. Begin by gathering all ingredients required for preparing papad ki sabzi, ensuring vegetables are washed, spices are measured, and proteins are cleaned.
2. Prepare Papad by chopping, marinating, soaking, or rinsing as traditionally required for the dish.
3. Heat oil, ghee, or butter in a kadhai or pot over medium flame until hot enough for sautéing.
4. Add aromatics such as onions, ginger, garlic, curry leaves, or whole spices and sauté until fragrant and lightly golden.
5. Add ground spices like turmeric, red chili, coriander, garam masala, or regional masalas and roast briefly to release their flavors.
6. Incorporate tomatoes, curd, coconut, tamarind, or other base ingredients depending on the dish and cook until the mixture thickens.
7. Add the prepared main ingredient along with any vegetables, dals, or meat pieces and mix thoroughly so they absorb the masala.
8. Pour in water, stock, or coconut milk (if applicable) and bring the mixture to a gentle boil.
9. Reduce heat to low and allow the dish to simmer until the main ingredient cooks fully and flavors deepen.
10. Taste and adjust seasoning, adding salt, spice, tanginess, or sweetness as needed.
11. Finish with garnishes such as coriander, ghee, cream, fried onions, or tempering (tadka) depending on regional preparation.
12. Serve hot with roti, naan, rice, dosa, or the traditional pairing for the dish.
